bib_record.title: -A measurement of the 14-C(N,g)15-C cross section at a stellar temperature of KT = 23.3 keV.

free_txt: H.B., F.K., And experimental site.
M.W., J.G.
P.E.K.
Main reference
The Karlsruhe pulsed 3.75 MV
Van de Graaff accelerator was used.
.The data were corrected for background and dead-time,
and for gain shifts during the measurements.
The activity of C-15 was measured with a HPGE
detector with a relative efficiency of 35 percent and
an energy resolution of 1.72 KeV at 1.33 MeV. The
efficiency of the detector was measured with calibra-
ted sources up to 1.84 MeV, and the range up to 11 MeV
was covered with the gamma-ray lines of the 992 keV
resonance of the radiative proton capture reaction on
Al-27. Also a Pu-238+C-13 source with a line at 6.13
MeV was used. To obtain a fast cyclic time, the detec-
tor was placed close to the neutron generation. It was
therefore well shielded. During the activity counting
phase the neutron generation was stopped by a proton
beam stop in the beam line. To reduce pile-up from the
activated nickel container, a lead shielding of 28 mm
was placed between the sample and the detector. In
this way the background count rate between 200 keV and
6.1 MeV was reduced to 10 kHz for a sample-detector
distance of 50 mm. This could be further reduced to
35 mm by replacing the Pb shield by 15 mm tungsten.
The neutron flux was monitored by a Li-6 glass
scintillation counter.
The uncertainty given includes contributions
from statistics, Ge-detector efficiency, Au standard
cross section, sample weight, C-15 gamma-ray line
intensity, Au-198 gamma-ray line intensity, neutron
multiple scattering, and misalignment of Au foils
relative to the C-14 sample.
The Karlsruhe pulsed 3.75 MV
Van de Graaff accelerator was used.
Neutrons were produced near the threshold.
.The neutron spectrum was similar to a Maxwellian
spectrum with a temperature of 25 keV.
Simultaneous activation of target material
and standard Au foils. A fast cyclic activation system
with a fast sample changer was used. Both the
irradiation and counting phases were chosen to be 10
sec. The Au activity was measured after the cyclic
activation.
Decay gammas
.The sample consisted of C-14 powder with an enrichment
of 89 percent, packed in a 0.0508 mm thick electro-
formed nickel container with a porous C-H2 plug glued
into the open end. The container had a volume of
2.97 cm * 1.20 cm * 0.5 cm. The effective area to be
irradiated was 2.97 cm * 1.20 cm = 3.56 cm2. Because
of a previous experiment with 500 MeV protons, the
nickel container was highly activated. The sample was
sandwiched between two gold foils of the same area,
having weights of 70 - 77 mg. Five individual runs of
the C-14 sample, each being about 5 days, were per-
formed.
.Data taken from table 3 of main ref.
